content:
I am an assistant professor in the Department of Wildlife Ecology and Conservation at the University of Florida (60% teaching; 40% research). I feel lucky to be able to dedicate my life to be an “ecological detective” solving the mysteries of nature. In this journey I collaborate with really cool and smart people including mathematicians, statisticians, engineers, computer scientists, geographers, epidemiologists, and social scientists. Modeling is one of my favorite tools to solve these mysteries because they can reduce complex problems into a reduced number of equations and assumptions. I transmit my passion for modeling in my classes where I use innovative and evidence-based approaches to teach quantitative topics to non-math majors. I also enjoy critical thinking, music, and salsa dancing!
I am lucky to contribute as part of the editorial board of Methods in Ecology and Evolution and as data papers editor for Ecology.
Visit our NSF-funded CONTERRITORIO project.
summary: I am an assistant professor in the Department of Wildlife Ecology and Conservation at the University of Florida (60% teaching; 40% research). I feel lucky to be able to dedicate my life to be an “ecological detective” solving the mysteries of nature.
title: Miguel Acevedo

content: For her MS degree, Nicole studied host-parasite co-evolutionary interactions in urban environments. She studied the consequences of infection by malaria parasites on Bananaquits, Puerto Rico’s most abudnant bird. She is currently a PhD student at the University of Toronto in Canada.
summary: For her MS degree, Nicole studied host-parasite co-evolutionary interactions in urban environments. She studied the consequences of infection by malaria parasites on Bananaquits, Puerto Rico’s most abudnant bird. She is currently a PhD student at the University of Toronto in Canada.
title: Nicole Gutierrez

content: Carly did her MS in the Department of Wildlife Ecology and Conservation. She is interested in quantitative ecology and genomics. For her thesis, she studied the evolutionary consequences of lizards (and their malaria parasites) re-colonizing secondary forests in Puerto Rico. She works in close collaboration with Riccardo Papa at the University of Puerto Rico.
summary: Carly did her MS in the Department of Wildlife Ecology and Conservation. She is interested in quantitative ecology and genomics. For her thesis, she studied the evolutionary consequences of lizards (and their malaria parasites) re-colonizing secondary forests in Puerto Rico.
title: Carly Fankhauser

content: For his MS degree, David studied evolutionary relationship between Anolis gundlachi and Plasmodium azurophilum. He is now a PhD student in the Department of Biological Science at the University of Pittsburgh.
summary: For his MS degree, David studied evolutionary relationship between Anolis gundlachi and Plasmodium azurophilum. He is now a PhD student in the Department of Biological Science at the University of Pittsburgh.
title: David Clark

content: Virnaliz is now a Florida Gator! She was an undergraduate researcher in the Quantitative Ecology Lab 1.0 at the University of Puerto Rico where she got the award of best undergraduate thesis. Now she is a PhD student in the School of Natural Resources and Environment at the University of Florida. She is being co-advised by Ethan White and interested in disease macro-ecology, complex systems and computational ecology.
summary: Virnaliz is now a Florida Gator! She was an undergraduate researcher in the Quantitative Ecology Lab 1.0 at the University of Puerto Rico where she got the award of best undergraduate thesis.
title: Virnaliz Cruz-Hernandez

content: John Michael is interested in quantitative population ecology and modeling. In his thesis, he studied the sources and consequences of heterogeneous mixing in vector-borne diseases. He is particularly interested in understanding how individual, and spatial heterogeneity influence disease dynamics of malaria in anoles in Puerto Rico and Florida.
summary: John Michael is interested in quantitative population ecology and modeling. In his thesis, he studied the sources and consequences of heterogeneous mixing in vector-borne diseases. He is particularly interested in understanding how individual, and spatial heterogeneity influence disease dynamics of malaria in anoles in Puerto Rico and Florida.
title: John Michael Toohey

content: Kylee is interested in conservation and behavioral ecology of the marine environment. Her theses assessed how increasing human-dolphin interactions in Sarasota Bay, Fl mediate reproduction and survival of Common Bottlenose Dolphins.
summary: Kylee is interested in conservation and behavioral ecology of the marine environment. Her theses assessed how increasing human-dolphin interactions in Sarasota Bay, Fl mediate reproduction and survival of Common Bottlenose Dolphins.
title: Kylee DiMaggio

title: Morgan Manning

content: For his PhD research, Nick is studied drivers of scales of effect on large and medium mammals globaly and the drivers of mammal distribution in the highly fragmented Atlantic Forest. His research interests stem from three years of service with the Peace Corps and WWF in Paraguay. Nick is advised by Dr. Lyn Branch and co-advised by Miguel.
summary: For his PhD research, Nick is studied drivers of scales of effect on large and medium mammals globaly and the drivers of mammal distribution in the highly fragmented Atlantic Forest. His research interests stem from three years of service with the Peace Corps and WWF in Paraguay.
title: Nicholas Gengler

content: Orlando is a PhD student in the School of Natural Resources and Environment. He wants to integrate different tools to understand bio and ecogeographic patterns of phenotypic and diversity traits in tropical birds from worldwide to local scales. He is coadviced by Scott Robinson, at the Florida Museum of Natural History. Orlando enjoys outdoor activities and salsa dancing!
summary: Orlando is a PhD student in the School of Natural Resources and Environment. He wants to integrate different tools to understand bio and ecogeographic patterns of phenotypic and diversity traits in tropical birds from worldwide to local scales.
title: Orlando Acevedo-Charry

content: Our undergraduate research team is composed of UF students from different Departments with varying interests. Our current group consist of Julia Ball, Brooke De Moore, Bella Gonzalez, and Vic Remley. They conduct key research in the lab including sampling lizard malaria in Puerto Rico, and conducting PCR and microscopy diagnosis. This is a group of highly skilled researchers. We are very lucky to have them as part of our group.
summary: Our undergraduate research team is composed of UF students from different Departments with varying interests. Our current group consist of Julia Ball, Brooke De Moore, Bella Gonzalez, and Vic Remley. They conduct key research in the lab including sampling lizard malaria in Puerto Rico, and conducting PCR and microscopy diagnosis.
title: Undergraduate Research Team

content:
Slides can be added in a few ways:
Create slides using Wowchemy’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes. Further event details, including page elements such as image galleries, can be added to the body of this page.
summary: An example event.
title: Example Event

content:
Congratulations to Carly for the successful defense of her MS thesis!
We are super happy to announce that Carly successfully defended her thesis titled ECO-EVOLUTIONARY DYNAMICS OF A THERMOCONFORMING ANOLE RECOLONIZING SECONDARY FOREST. For her thesis she compared genomic diversity and structure of Anolis gundlachi among forests of different ages in Puerto Rico. She also collaborated in multiple other projects in our lab and co-authored three peer-reviewed publications. We wish her the very best in her future endeavors.
summary: Congratulations to Carly for the successful defense of her MS thesis!
title: Carly defended her MS thesis

content:
Our undergraduate research team presented their reserach
Many studies on habitat-species relationship evaluate the role of habitat variables using buffers of certain sizes. Still, what is the optimal size?
summary: Our undergraduate research team presented their reserach
title: Matt, Brynn and Megan presented in the undergraduate research symposium

content:
Nick just graduated from his PhD! Congratulations Dr. Gengler!
Nick initial PhD idea was to work on quantitative approaches to better understand and manage mammal communities in Paraguay. And then COVID19 happened. He couldn’t travel to Paraguay so instead, Nick developed a pretty clever plan b, to address one of the most important challenges in landscape ecology. As part of his dissertation Nick conducted a global analysis compare the scale of effect of landscape composition and configuration of forest mammals. Nick’s degree was supported by an (NSF-GRF)[https://www.nsfgrfp.org/]. We are grateful of NSF for supporting his career. Paraguay didn’t happened for his PhD, but…he landed a position with local NGO in Paraguay working in mammal conservation. Nick’s story is one of perseverance and success.
summary: Nick just graduated from his PhD! Congratulations Dr. Gengler!
title: Congratulations Dr. Gengler

content:
We are back from Portland, where we did a workshop on Data Papers and the future of open science at ESA 2023.
The future of ecology is intrinsically tied to our ability to conduct open science. Data Papers are a special type of paper in Ecology where data and metadata are published to be reused. Our group of ESA Data Paper Editors composed of Grace DiRenzo, Hao Ye, Simona Picardi, and myself are working towards a re conceptualization of this important type of paper. We are following a data-driven process that includes gathering input from the community. As part of this process we led a special session at ESA where our community engaged in a super fun and highly engaging brainstorming session. Working with this group is a real luxury! Stay tuned as we we will announce soon the new features of Data Papers 2.0!
summary: We are back from Portland, where we did a workshop on Data Papers and the future of open science at ESA 2023.
title: Data Papers 2.0 (ESA 2023)

content:
Congratulations to Miguel for getting the NACTA Educator Award recognition.
North American Colleges and Teachers of Agriculture (NACTA) recognized Miguel with the NACTA Educator Award which recognizes those individuals whose efforts represent the very best in agricultural higher education.
summary: Congratulations to Miguel for getting the NACTA Educator Award recognition.
title: Miguel gets NACTA Educators Award

content:
We are back from the field collecting data on lizard malaria in Puerto Rico.
This was an awesome and productive field season! Our first mission was to collect data for our long-term study of lizard-malaria dynamics. (Yes, lizards get malaria. No, you will not likely get malaria from a lizard). One of the biggest mysteries in this system is the vector identity. We know that malaria gets transmitted among lizards by an insect vector, but we don’t know who it is. This field season, we brought the big guns! We joined forces with Don Yee and Lawrence Reeves…and…during a night walk we finally saw our suspected vector biting lizards! We are working as a team to report our findings in a peer-reviewed publication. Needless to say that we are super excited about the discovery!
summary: We are back from the field collecting data on lizard malaria in Puerto Rico.
title: We are back from Puerto Rico (Summer 2023)

content:
We are back from the Colombian Amazon in an expedition to assess Orlando’s study sites.
The Amazon…did we need to say more?! What a fantastic expedition. We spent nine days in Vaupés, Colombia-one of the most isolated parts of the Colombian Amazon where Orlando wants to do one of the chapters of his dissertation. We were joined by Scott Robinson so…yes…we were interested in those hyper diverse bird communities, particularly those that lived white sand forests. Orlando’s questions about climate change and bird-species assemblages in the Amazon are timely, the study site magical, and the local indigenous communities welcoming. We can’t wait to be back!
summary: We are back from the Colombian Amazon in an expedition to assess Orlando’s study sites.
title: We are back from Mitu
